content.text: The Hyperfy community has been actively developing and refining features across multiple areas of the platform, focusing on technical improvements, user experience, and agentic workflows. Key updates include emote integration, skinned mesh support, deployment fixes, and enhanced building tools.

Emote Integration and Skinned Meshes: ashxn.eth introduced a sit emote using player.applyEffect and props, and announced support for skinned meshes in the dev branch. This enables non-humanoid animations (e.g., pets, mounts) with crossfade support between animations using a fade parameter.

Deployment and Persistence: Users faced issues deploying Hyperfy on Digital Ocean. ashxn.eth clarified that .env variables must match the public IP and HTTPS is required for file hashing and object persistence. These issues were resolved, enabling successful deployment.

Custom Events and Draw Calls: Custom event handling was demonstrated using app.emit and world.on. Discussions on vertex colors and draw call optimization highlighted the importance of Blender export settings and mesh structure for performance.

First-Person Building and Drone Control: A drone object was introduced to enable first-person building while keeping the avatar visible. devbyte_00 enhanced this by allowing remote drone control via keybinds, improving usability and immersion.

Object Optimization and Asset Importing: Large object placement issues prompted optimization efforts. Community members shared experiences importing external assets like a Shell gas station model from GTA5, showcasing the platformâ€™s flexibility.

Modular Player Mechanics and Snap Features: themattempire proposed a modular system for toggling player abilities and weapons, supported by ashxn.eth and d_maximus. Snap points can now be added programmatically using app.create('snap'), enabling dynamic object interactions.

Agentic Workflows and LLM Integration: d_maximus and rickydata1 discussed advanced prompt engineering using multiple LLMs in feedback loops. The 'jintern' project was introduced to embed organizational knowledge into LLM agents for code review and autonomous script validation, aiming for self-improving AI workflows.

Feature Requests and Documentation: Community members requested features like object scaling, energy bars for dash mechanics, and packaging experiences into .hyp files. Documentation updates were suggested for drone usage, snap point creation, and modular mechanics.
